page.title: 02A Church in Wolverhampton
page.content: St.Peter's Church stands in the centre of Wolverhampton,dominating the town and setting a fine example of local history.The present building is on a site originally occupied by a minster church built by Lady Wulfruna in 994 AD.The large,mainly 15th century,parish church is built of red stone and,after much restoration,appears as it did in the 16th century with the exception of the chancel,rebuilt completely in 1867. At the entrance is a finely carved porch given in memory of Sir Charles Mander,a former Mayor of the Borough, who died in 1929.There is a gallery at the west end of the nave,erected by the Company of Merchant Taylors for the use of boys at the local Grammar School,of which they were governors.It bears the date 1616 and the herald of Sir Stephen Jenyns,the school's founder.
